step1.sentence: The company claims to value work-life balance, but many employees feel management is just paying lip service to the idea while demanding long hours.

step2.story: The new policy promised more diversity in hiring, but the staff quickly noticed it was all talk. Management paid lip service to inclusion without changing a single interview process. Eventually, morale dropped as people realized nothing would actually change.

step3.story: When the environmental report was released, the city council issued a bold statement pledging to cut carbon emissions by half within five years. Citizens applauded and held signs at the town hall meeting, hopeful for real action. But six months passed, and not one new policy had been enacted. The mayor continued to attend green energy conferences and pose for photos with activists, yet the budget for renewable projects remained untouched. A local journalist dug into the numbers and published a piece showing the council was simply paying lip service to sustainability. The public outrage that followed finally forced the council to commit real funding to the cause.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 입술로만 봉사한다, 즉 말로만 어떤 것을 지지하거나 동의한다는 뜻이다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 실제로는 아무런 행동이나 노력을 기울이지 않으면서 겉으로만 동의하거나 지지하는 척할 때 사용한다. 주로 정치인, 기업, 또는 개인이 원칙이나 가치를 말로만 내세울 때 비판적으로 쓰인다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 'lip service'는 17세기 영어에서 등장한 표현으로, 입술(lip)로만 하는 봉사(service), 즉 진심이 없는 말만의 약속이나 지지를 가리키며 성경에서도 유사한 개념이 나타난다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 부정적이고 비판적인 뉘앙스가 강하다. 말과 행동이 일치하지 않는 위선적인 태도를 꼬집을 때 쓰이며, 상대방을 직접적으로 비난하는 어감을 가진다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Politicians often pay lip service to education reform without actually increasing school funding.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 정치인들은 학교 예산을 실제로 늘리지 않으면서 교육 개혁에 대해 말로만 지지하는 경우가 많다.
